Graphical abstract To enhance the hydrodesulfurization (HDS) activity of SiO2-supported Rh phosphide catalysts, various second metal-added Rh–P catalysts were developed; furthermore, the effect of the addition of the second metal on the HDS performance was examined. The second metals (M: Ru, Pt, and Ir) were selected as per the Sabatier principle. In situ X-ray diffraction revealed the formation of an Rh2P phase in the Rh–M–P catalyst after reduction. The addition of Ru and Pt to the Rh–P catalyst enhanced the C−S bond cleavage activity, whereas the addition of Ir had virtually no effect. The Rh–Pt–P catalyst demonstrated the highest HDS activity among Rh–M–P catalysts. The characterization results revealed the presence of positively charged Pt on the Rh–Pt–P catalyst surface, in which Pt and Rh cooperatively act as active sites to enhance the C−S bond cleavage activity. Keywords Rhodium phosphide catalyst Platinum Hydrodesulfurization C−S bond cleavage activity 1 Introduction In the petroleum industry, the development of highly active hydrodesulfurization (HDS) catalysts to prevent environment deterioration is a pressing concern [1–4]. In general, sulfided CoMo/Al2O3 is extensively used as a catalyst for the HDS process, and Co–Mo–S is known to be its active phase. In these type of catalysts, phosphides [1,3,5–22] have received considerable attention as new active phases. In particular, our group [17–21] and that of Bussell [1,22] reported that Rh2P supported on SiO2 exhibited high and stable catalytic activity for the HDS reaction. In our previous study, we reported that an Rh–P/SiO2 catalyst with high hydrogenation activity possessed high activity for the HDS of 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT) [21]. Using this catalyst, fully hydrogenated products, i.e., dimethylbicyclohexyls, yielded high selectivity; however, this reaction produced hydrogenated 4,6-DMDBTs with higher selectivity than the analogous process using a sulfided NiMo/Al2O3 catalyst [21]. This shows that the Rh–P/SiO2 catalyst shows lower C−S cleavage activity than the sulfided NiMo/Al2O3 catalyst. Among metal sulfide catalysts, RuS2 was reported by Chianelli et al. to exhibit the highest catalytic activity for the HDS of dibenzothiophene (DBT) [23,24]. According to the Sabatier principle, the metal–sulfur (M−S) bond strength revealed the critical parameter for the high HDS activity of metal sulfides [23,24]. Especially, the RuS2 catalyst favors the direct desulfurization route [25–27]. Accordingly, assuming that the optimal M−S bond strength leads to high C−S bond cleavage activity, the low C−S bond cleavage activity of Rh-based catalysts can be attributed to the insufficient strength of the Rh–S bond. Therefore, the low C−S bond cleavage activity of Rh-based catalysts could be enhanced by adding a second metal that forms strong M−S bonds to control the average M−S bond strength in the catalyst. With the aim to improve the performance of the Rh–P/SiO2 catalyst, certain noble metals with diverse M−S bond strengths, including Ir (the strength of the Ir–S bond is slightly lower than that of the Ru–S bond), Ru (the strength of the Ru–S bond is optimal for the HDS reaction), and Pt (the Pt–S bond is stronger than the Ru–S bond), were used as additives in this study. The HDS performance of the resultant second metal-added Rh–P/SiO2 catalysts was examined. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Silica (SiO2, BET surface area 295 m2 g−1) was supplied by Nippon Aerosil Co. The second metal-added Rh–P/SiO2 (Rh–M–P) catalyst was prepared using a coimpregnation method as per previously reported procedures [17–21]. Rhodium(III) chloride trihydrate (RhCl3·3H2O, Kanto Chemical Co., >78% as RhCl3), iridium(IV) chloride (IrCl4, Wako Chemical Co., 99.5%), ruthenium(III) chloride trihydrate (RuCl3·3H2O, Kanto Chemical Co., 99.9%), hydrogen hexachloroplatinate(IV) hexahydrate (H2PtCl6·6H2O, Kanto Chemical Co., >98.5%), and ammonium dihydrogen phosphate (NH4H2PO4, Kanto Chemical Co., >99.0%) aqueous solutions were used as precursors and dissolved in water. In a 100 mL beaker, 0.935 g of SiO2, 12.8 mL of RhCl3·3H2O aqueous solution (0.0384 mol/L), 0.056 g of NH4H2PO4, and 37.2 mL of H2O were mixed. The Rh loading amount was 5.0 wt% for the Rh–P catalyst, 4.85 wt% for the Rh–M–P catalysts. Pt and Ir loading was 0.28 wt%, and the Ru loading was 0.15 wt%. The molar ratio [M/(Rh + M)] for these catalysts was 0.03; furthermore, the P loading was 1.5 wt% (P/(Rh + M) molar ratio = 1.0). After impregnation, the Rh–M–P catalyst was dried at 110 °C for 24 h, followed by heat treatment under N2 (AIR WATER Inc., 99.995%) stream at 450 °C for 1 h to decompose the salts. The ramp rate for N2 treatment was 10 °C min−1. After this treatment, the catalyst was sieved into 30–42 mesh granules and calcined at 500 °C for 4 h. Following the same impregnation method, a Pt–P catalyst was prepared with Pt and P loadings of 5.0 and 3.0 wt%, respectively. 2.2 HDS of thiophene and 4,6-DMDBT The HDS of thiophene (C4H4S, ACROS ORGANICS, 99.5 %) was performed at 350 °C under a pressure of 0.1 MPa using a conventional fixed-bed flow reactor to estimate the catalytic activity. The Rh–M–P catalyst (0.1 g) was charged in the quartz reactor and heated (10 °C min−1) in an He (AIR WATER Inc., 99.995%) stream (30 mL min−1) at 500 °C for 1 h, followed by reduction with H2 (AIR WATER Inc., 99.995%) at 400 °C–700 °C for 1 h. An H2/C4H4S gas mixture (H2/C4H4S = 30) was obtained by passing an H2 stream via a C4H4S trap cooled at 0 °C, and this gas mixture was introduced in the quartz reactor (W/F = 37.9 g h mol−1, W: catalyst weight, F: flow rate of reactant). The reaction products were analyzed using a gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). A silicone DC-550 column (length: 2 m, temperature: 110 °C) was used to estimate C4H4S conversion, and an Al2O3/KCl plot column (ID: 0.53 mm, length: 25 m, film thickness: 10 μm, temperature: 60 °C–190 °C, rate: 7.5 °C min−1) was used to separate the produced hydrocarbons. The HDS of 4,6-DMDBT was performed using a fixed-bed flow reactor at 350 °C under 4.0 MPa. The catalysts reduced at the optimal temperature were cooled to 25 °C in an He stream (30 mL min−1), followed by passivation with 5% O2/He (30 mL min−1) for 0.5 h. A mixture of passivated catalyst (0.2 g) and quartz sand (0.8 g) was charged in the stainless steel reactor and heated (10 °C min−1) in an H2 stream (1 L h−1) to the reaction temperature. Then, a 0.024 mol L−1 of 4,6-DMDBT (ACROS ORGANICS, 95%) xylene (Junsei Chemical Co., >83% xylenes) solution was introduced in the reactor using a high-pressure pump. The reaction products were analyzed using a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu, GC-14B) equipped with a DB-5 column (30 m) and an FID. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The as-prepared Rh–M–P catalysts were characterized using temperature-programmed reduction (TPR), X-ray diffraction (XRD), carbon monoxide (CO) adsorption, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy of adsorbed CO, and X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) analyses. TPR profiles were obtained using a Shimadzu GC-8A gas chromatograph. Before the measurement, the catalyst (0.1 g) was pretreated in an He stream (30 mL min−1) at 500 °C for 1 h. After this treatment, the catalysts were cooled to 30 °C in an He stream, and the He was switched to a 5 vol% H2/N2 gas (Air water Inc.) mixture at 30 °C for 0.5 h. The TPR profile was recorded over a temperature range of 30 °C to 850 °C at 10 °C min−1 using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) to monitor the H2 consumption. Water was removed using a molecular sieve trap. The XRD patterns of catalysts were measured using a Rigaku Ultima IV equipped with an in situ gas flow and a heating system (reactor X) and a Cu Kα radiation source operated at 30 kV and 15 mA. XRD measurements were performed with a 5 vol% H2/N2 gas flow (30 mL min−1) between 30 °C and 650 °C. The amount of CO adsorption on Rh–M–P catalysts was measured using the pulse method. Accordingly, the Rh–M–P catalyst (0.1 g) was reduced with H2 at 450 °C–750 °C for 1 h before CO adsorption. CO (Air water Inc., 99.9%) was injected on the catalyst layer at 25 °C using a six-way valve with a sampling loop (1.0 mL). The CO uptake was measured using a Shimadzu GC-8A gas chromatograph equipped with a TCD. TEM observations were performed using a JEOL JEM-2100F. The condition of TEM operation was an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. The particle size distribution and average particle size were determined from the measurements of 100 particles in the TEM micrographs. FT-IR spectra of adsorbed CO were measured using a JASCO FT-IR 4200ST with an in situ cell. A catalyst disk having a 20 mm diameter was loaded on the in situ cell. Then, the catalyst was treated with He at 500 °C for 1 h, subjected to reduction with H2 at 350 °C for 1 h, and cooled to room temperature in an He stream. CO chemisorption was conducted by maintaining the catalyst in a stream of 1 vol% CO/He mixed gas at room temperature for 5 min. The FT-IR adsorption spectrum was recorded in an He stream at room temperature. XANES was performed at SPring-8 (BL01B1 and BL14B2). Rh K-edge XANES measurements were conducted using an in situ quartz cell in transmission mode under an H2 flow (100 mL min−1) and two ionization chambers. The measurement temperature ranged from room temperature to 650 °C. Pt L3-edge XANES measurements were conducted using a Ge single-element solid-state detector at room temperature. To avoid exposure to air, the reduced catalysts were sealed under N2. Rh2P powder (Tanaka Kikinzoku Kogyo K.K.) was mixed with BN, and a pellet having a diameter of 8 mm was prepared. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of the reduction temperature on the formation of active sites 3.1.1 TPR profiles of the Rh–M–P catalysts As reported previously, the reduction temperature is one of the most important factors to prepare Rh2P catalysts [17–20]. In this study, TPR measurements were performed to clarify the effect of the addition of a second metal on the reducibility of the Rh–P catalyst. Fig. 1 shows the TPR profiles of Rh–M–P catalysts. In the TPR profile of the Rh–P catalyst [Fig. 1 (a)], a large peak attributed to Rh2O3 reduction was observed at ∼ 90 °C and small peaks attributed to the reduction of phosphate interacting with Rh species [18] or the SiO2 support [18,19] appeared at ∼ 250 °C and 655 °C, respectively [Fig. 1 (b)]. The peak corresponding to phosphate reduction interacting with Rh species hardly changed after the addition of the second metal. However, the peak of phosphate interacting with the SiO2 support shifted to a higher temperature (∼700 °C) on addition of Ru and Pt. In the Rh–Ir–P catalyst, this peak appeared at a significantly higher temperature (at ∼ 750 °C). These results indicate that the reduction temperature for phosphide formation increased after the addition of the second metal. 3.1.2 In situ XRD patterns of Rh–M–P catalysts In situ XRD measurements were performed to examine the effect of the reduction temperature on the Rh2P formation. In the XRD patterns of the Rh–P catalyst [Fig. 2 (a)], a broad peak (34.2°) for Rh2O3 appeared at 30 °C. After reduction at 100 °C, peaks attributable to Rh were observed, which agreed with the reduction temperature (∼90 °C) observed in the TPR profile of the Rh–P catalyst [Fig. 1 (a)]. At 350 °C, small peaks for Rh2P appeared but large Rh peaks were also observed. The intensity of Rh2P peaks increased with increase in reduction temperature to > 350 °C, and the peaks for Rh vanished at 550 °C. In the XRD patterns of all M-added Rh–P catalysts [Fig. 2 (b)–(d)], the same trend was observed for forming Rh2P. Moreover, as can be seen from the TPR profiles (Fig. 1), the peak temperature attributed to the reduction of phosphate on SiO2 increased after adding M. Nevertheless, the P loading in a stoichiometry of P/Rh = 1.0 was sufficient to form Rh2P. These results show that the Rh2P phase was exclusively obtained via the reduction of phosphate species interacting with Rh. Moreover, a small peak for Pt appeared in the XRD pattern of the Rh–Pt–P catalyst at 100 °C and 350 °C [Fig. 2 (c)], whereas the peaks for Ru and Ir were not observed [Fig. 2 (b), (d)]. Furthermore, the full width at half maximum of the Rh2P peak at 46.4° in the Rh–Ir–P catalyst was narrower than that of other catalysts, indicating that Ir addition decreased the dispersion of Rh2P. The crystalline size of Rh2P was calculated using Scherrer’s equation, and the results are listed in Table 1 . In the Rh–P catalyst, the crystalline size of Rh2P increased with increase in the reduction temperature. At the same reduction temperature, the crystalline size of Rh2P in the Rh–Ir–P catalyst was larger than that in the Rh–P catalyst. Moreover, after adding Ru and Pt to the Rh–P catalyst, the crystalline size of Rh2P slightly decreased. 3.1.3 CO uptake of Rh–M–P catalysts The CO uptakes of Rh–M–P catalysts reduced at different temperatures are shown in Fig. 3 and Table S1 . In the Rh–P catalyst, the CO uptake decreased with increase in the reduction temperature, which indicates that high reduction temperatures induced the sintering of Rh species [18,19]. After the addition of the second metal to the Rh–P catalyst, the CO uptake decreased at any reduction temperature with the Rh–Ir–P catalyst showing the lowest CO uptake among Rh–M–P catalysts. This result agrees with the result of XRD patterns (Fig. 2 and Table 1). 3.1.4 TEM images of the Rh–M–P catalysts The TEM images and particle size distributions of the Rh–M–P catalysts reduced at optimal temperature for HDS activities (see 3.2.1) are shown in Figs. S1 and S2 . The average particle sizes of the Rh–M–P catalysts calculated from TEM images are listed in Table 2 . In any catalyst, the average particle was hardly changed by addition of second metals. The average particle size for Rh–P catalyst reduced at 550 °C (6.3 nm) was the same as crystallite size (6.2 nm, Table 1). The same trend was also observed in the Rh–Pt–P and Rh–Ru–P catalysts. On the other hand, average particle size (6.3 nm) of Rh–Ir–P catalyst was smaller than crystallite size (8.2 nm, Table 1). In the Rh–P catalyst with higher P loading (above P/Rh ratio 1.5), the average particle size calculated from TEM images was also smaller than crystallite size [18]. The CO uptake of Rh–Ir–P catalyst reduced at 600 °C was lower than those of other Rh–M–P catalysts, as shown in Fig. 3. These results indicate that Rh sites of Rh2P in the Rh–Ir–P catalyst would be covered by reduced P [18]. 3.2 Effect of second metal addition on the C–S bond cleavage activity of the Rh–P catalyst 3.2.1 HDS of thiophene Previously, we reported that high reduction temperatures accelerate the formation of Rh2P and sintering [18,19]. Indeed, Rh2P formation and sintering proceeded with increase in the reduction temperature in this study, as shown in Section 3.1. Therefore, the optimal reduction temperature for C4H4S HDS activity of Rh–M–P catalysts was examined. As shown in Fig. S3 , the total area of the GC-FID peak for thiophene HDS over the Rh–P catalyst reduced at 550 °C remained constant on increasing the reaction time. The same trend was observed for all catalysts; therefore, coke deposition would hardly occur in the Rh–M–P catalysts. Fig. 4 and Table S1 show the relationship between the reduction temperature and HDS activities of Rh–M–P catalysts. In the Rh–P catalyst, the optimal reduction temperature for HDS was observed at 550 °C. Moreover, the optimal reduction temperature was 600 °C for Pt- and Ir-added catalysts and 450 °C for the Rh–Ru–P catalyst. The Rh–Pt–P catalyst reduced at 600 °C demonstrated the highest HDS activity among Rh–M–P catalysts. The turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated using the CO uptake to evaluate the effect of M addition on the HDS activity of the Rh–P catalyst. Fig. 5 shows the effect of the reduction temperature on the TOF of Rh–M–P catalysts. The TOF of the Rh–P catalyst increased with increase in the reduction temperature, which can be explained by the formation of Rh2P. The TOF of the Rh–Ru–P catalyst was the same as that of the Rh–P catalyst. Moreover, the TOF of the Rh–P catalyst was enhanced by adding Pt and Ir. Furthermore, the TOF of the Rh–Pt–P catalyst remarkably increased with increase in the reduction temperature from 550 °C to 600 °C, indicating the formation of new active sites including Pt. Furthermore, the order of TOF values for the Rh–M–P catalysts reduced at optimal temperatures was as follows: Rh–Pt–P ≈ Rh–Ir–P > Rh–P > Rh–Ru–P. The TOF values of the Rh–P catalyst reduced at 550 °C and Rh–Pt–P catalyst reduced at 600 °C were 0.061 and 0.076 s−1, respectively. Thus, a small amount of added Pt enhanced the TOF value of the Rh–P catalyst up to 1.2 times. The TOF of an Ni2P/SiO2 catalyst (P/Ni = 0.80) for the HDS of thiophene at 370 °C was 0.021 s−1 [6], and Oyama et al. reported that an Ni2P/MCM–41 catalyst demonstrated a TOF of 0.0082 s−1 for the HDS of thiophene at 300 °C [7]. Moreover, we reported that the TOF values of Pt/SiO2 and Pt/Al2O3 catalysts for the HDS of thiophene at 350 °C were 0.0014 s−1 (5.0 h−1) and 0.0018 s−1 (6.6 h−1), respectively [28]. The TOF value of the Rh–Pt–P catalyst (0.076 s−1) was remarkably higher than that of supported Ni2P and Pt catalysts. Moreover, as shown in Table S2 , the TOF of the Pt–P catalyst for thiophene HDS was 0.047 s−1. This TOF was lower than that of the Rh–P catalyst, indicating that Pt interacts strongly with Rh2P to form a new active site in the Rh–Pt–P catalyst. Table S3 shows the effect of W/F on product selectivities in the thiophene HDS over the Rh–P catalyst. The maximum selectivity for 1,3-butadiene (1,3-BD) was observed at a W/F of 0.38 g h mol−1. The highest selectivity for tetrahydrothiophene (THT) was obtained at a W/F of 1.90 g h mol−1. These results indicate that the hydrogenation of 1,3-BD quickly proceeds to form butenes compared with the hydrogenation of thiophene and the C−S bond cleavage of THT. The C−S bond cleavage activity of the Rh–M–P catalysts was examined. Table 3 lists the product selectivities in the HDS of C4H4S over the Rh–M–P catalysts reduced at the optimal temperatures. For a catalyst with high C−S bond cleavage ability, the selectivity for THT should be low. At the 1.8%-1.9% conversion, the Rh–Pt–P catalyst showed lower THT selectivity (6.2%) than the Rh–P catalyst (11.0%). At the 5.3%-7.0% conversion, the Rh–Ru–P catalyst also showed lower THT selectivity (8.7%) than the Rh–P catalyst (12.8%), whereas that of the Rh–Ir–P catalyst (18.0%) was remarkably higher. These results indicate that Ru and Pt enhanced the C−S bond cleavage activity of the Rh–P catalyst. The THT selectivity was also evaluated at the higher conversion (around 67%–70%). The THT selectivity changed only slightly after the second metal addition. However, the Rh–Ru–P and Rh–Pt–P catalysts showed lower THT selectivity (1.4% and 1.5%, respectively) than the Rh–P catalyst (1.8%), whereas that of the Rh–Ir–P catalyst (1.9%) was slightly higher. These results revealed that the order of the C−S bond cleavage activities of the Rh–M−P catalysts was as follows; Rh–Ru–P > Rh–Pt–P > Rh–P > Rh–Ir–P. Toulhoat et al. reported that the experimental M−S bonding strength in Rh2S3, IrS2, RuS2, and PtS was 44.30, 49.15, 50.74, and 55.69 kcal/mol, respectively [29]. Because of its moderate M−S bond strength, RuS2 is the most active HDS catalyst among transition metal sulfides [23,24,29]. Accordingly, the C−S bond cleavage activity of the Rh–P catalyst would be enhanced by adding Ru with an optimal M−S bond strength. Furthermore, because the Pt−S bond is stronger than the Ru−S bond, the C−S bond cleavage activity of the Rh–Pt–P catalyst could be expected to be lower than that of the Rh–Ru–P catalyst. However, the addition of Ir, which shows similar M−S bond strength to Ru [29], hardly affected the C−S bond cleavage activity of the Rh–P catalyst. CO uptake and average particle size distribution revealed that the Ir addition facilitates formation of P-covered Rh and Ir sites. Thus, P atoms would block the effect of Ir addition on the C−S bond cleavage activity of the Rh–P catalyst. Because the amount of Rh–Pt–P catalyst required to obtain 70% conversion was the same as that of the Rh–P catalyst (0.100 g), whereas that of the Rh–Ru–P catalyst was higher (0.113 g), Pt was selected as the best additive to enhance the C−S bond cleavage activity of the Rh–P catalyst. Then, to clarify the effect of the Pt addition on the performance of the Rh–P catalyst, the HDS activity and product selectivity of a physically mixed Rh–P and Pt–P (Rh–P + Pt–P) catalyst was evaluated. Because a single PtP2 phase was obtained after reduction at 600 °C (the optimal temperature for the Rh–Pt–P catalyst), the Pt–P catalyst was used to prepare the physically mixed catalyst ( Fig. S4 ). Table 4 lists the THT selectivities of certain Pt-added Rh–P catalysts. At a low conversion of ∼ 3%, the THT selectivity of the Rh–Pt–P catalyst was lower than that of the Rh–P catalyst (Table 3 ). However, the THT selectivities of the Rh–P + Pt–P and Pt–P catalysts were higher than that of the Rh–P catalyst. Furthermore, the Rh–Pt–P catalyst demonstrated higher 1,3-BD selectivity than other catalysts. These results showed that Rh and added Pt cooperatively acted as active sites in the Rh–Pt–P catalyst but not separately. 3.2.2 HDS of 4,6-DMDBT Next, the activity of the Rh–Pt–P catalyst for the HDS of 4,6-DMDBT was examined, and the results are shown in Fig. 6 . In the first 1.5 h of reaction, the HDS activity of the Rh–Pt–P catalyst increased with the reaction time. For the Rh–P catalyst, the HDS activity increased from 1 to 3 h of reaction. The same trend was also observed in the Rh–Pt–P catalyst. Oyama et al. reported that active phase of Ni2P/SiO2 catalyst is a phosphosulfide [5]. Bussell et al. reported that Rh2P catalyst after HDS of dibenzothiophene contains small amount of S [22]. Thus, formation of phosphosulfide phase would enhance the catalytic activity of Rh2P. Subsequently, the HDS activities of these catalysts slightly decreased with increase in time on stream. After reaction for 10 h, the HDS activity of the Rh–Pt–P catalyst was slightly higher than that of the Rh–P catalyst. Table 5 lists the product selectivities in the HDS of 4,6-DMDBT over the Rh–Pt–P and Rh–P catalysts. For the Rh–P catalyst, the selectivities for hydrogenated DBTs (HDBTs) and DMDBTs (HDMDBTs) were 2.6% and 3.7%, respectively. The addition of Pt decreased these selectivities (2.0% and 3.1%). Moreover, the selectivity for methylcyclohexyltoluenes (MCHTs) on the Rh–P catalyst (49.7%) increased upon Pt addition (51.4%). However, the selectivity for 3,3′-dimethylbiphenyl (DMBP) over the Rh–P catalyst (24.3%) decreased after adding Pt (23.5%). However, the selectivity for dimethylbicyclohexyls (DMBCHs) was hardly changed on Pt addition. These results indicate that the Rh–Pt–P catalyst possesses higher C−S bond cleavage activity for HDBTs and HDMDBTs than the Rh–P catalyst. The TOF of the Rh–P and Rh–Pt–P catalysts for 4,6-DMDBT HDS were 0.0014 s−1 and 0.0017 s−1, respectively. The TOF of Rh–Pt–P catalyst showed 1.2 times higher than that of the Rh–P catalyst. On the other hand, Pt–P catalyst showed a high TOF value (0.0083 s−1). Fig. S5 shows the XRD pattern of Pt–P catalyst after HDS of 4,6-DMDBT. The peaks for PtP2, Pt, and PtS2 were observed. In the HDS of 4,6-DMDBT, PtP2 would reduce with H2 to form Pt at high pressure. Since Pt is easily covered by P [19], CO uptake of Pt catalyst is decreased by P addition. Furthermore, Pt reacts with H2S to form PtS2. Thus, high TOF value for Pt–P catalyst was attributed to underestimation of CO uptake and/or formation of PtS2. Table 5 also lists the product selectivities in the HDS of 4,6-DMDBT over the Pt–P catalyst. The Pt–P catalyst showed remarkably lower selectivities for DMBCHs and MCHTs than the Rh–Pt–P and Rh–P catalysts. Furthermore, the Pt–P catalyst demonstrated significantly higher HDBTs and HDMDBTs selectivities than the Rh–Pt–P and Rh–P catalysts, indicating that the C−S bond cleavage activity of the Pt–P catalyst was significantly lower than that of Rh-based catalysts. Therefore, Pt atoms in the Rh–Pt–P catalyst most likely form a different type of active sites from that of the Pt–P catalyst. 3.3 Characterization of the Rh–Pt–P catalyst 3.3.1 FT-IR spectra of CO adsorbed on the Rh–Pt–P catalysts Fig. 7 shows the FT-IR spectra of CO adsorbed on the Rh–P and Rh–Pt–P catalysts. The remarkable peaks for gem-dicarbonyl (2106 and 2035 cm−1) and linear (2073 cm−1) adsorption species and a small peak for bridge species (1880 cm−1) were observed in the spectra of Rh–P and Rh–Pt–P catalysts at room temperature. In supported Rh catalysts, the intensity of the peak for bridge species was reported to increase with reduction in Rh dispersion [30,31]. Moreover, gem-dicarbonyl species were observed on single Rh sites (highly dispersed Rh sites) [31,32]. Thus, the Rh dispersion seems to strongly affect the state of CO adsorption. Nevertheless, for two catalysts having almost the same dispersion, the intensity ratio of gem-dicarbonyl species to linear species (D/L ratio) would be constant. The dispersion of Rh species in the Rh–Pt–P catalyst was the same as that in the Rh–P catalyst, as shown in Table 1 and Fig. 3; therefore, the D/L ratio of both catalysts should be the same. However, the actual D/L ratio of the Rh–Pt–P catalyst (1.63) was lower than that of the Rh–P catalyst (1.79). Linear (∼2070 cm−1) and bridge (∼1840 cm−1) species are present in Pt catalysts [33,34]. As per these results, CO molecules would be linearly adsorbed on Pt sites in the Rh–Pt–P catalyst. Thus, the low D/L ratio of the Rh–Pt–P catalyst revealed the presence of Pt atoms on the surface of Rh2P particles or on the SiO2 support. Furthermore, the amount of exposed Rh sites was calculated as per the CO uptake and D/L ratio ( Table S4 ). The TOF of the Rh–Pt–P catalyst calculated on the basis of the exposed Rh sites (0.092 s−1) was about 4.4 times higher than that of the Ni2P/SiO2 catalyst (0.021 s−1) [6]. 3.3.2 XANES analysis of the Rh–Pt–P catalyst Fig. 8 shows the in situ Rh K-edge XANES of the Rh–Pt–P catalyst. The XANES recorded at 450 °C revealed the presence of metallic Rh. However, the peak for metallic Rh was small in the in situ XRD pattern of the same catalyst [Fig. 2 (c)], whereas the peaks for Rh2P were clearly observed at 450 °C. In our previous study, the surface of Rh particles was reported to react with P to form a core–shell structure comprising an Rh2P shell and an Rh core [18,35]. Above 550 °C, the shape of XANES was similar to that of Rh2P. At the same reduction temperature, no metallic Rh peaks were observed in the in situ XRD pattern [Fig. 2 (c)]. Thus, after reduction at > 550 °C, almost all Rh atoms reacted with P to form Rh2P. Furthermore, regardless of reduction temperature, the energy origin (E0) of the Rh K-edge XANES were higher than that of Rh foil (Table 6 ), which agrees with an electron transfer from Rh to P [22,35,36]. Fig. 9 shows the Pt L3-edge XANES of the Rh–Pt–P catalysts prepared at different reduction temperatures. The shape of the XANES for the Rh–Pt–P catalyst reduced at 450 °C was similar to that of Pt foil. Furthermore, the E0 of this catalyst was almost the same as that of Pt foil, as shown in Table 6. These results show that Pt hardly reacts with P. Furthermore, the white line intensity and E0 of the Pt L3-edge XANES of the Rh–Pt–P catalyst increased with increase in reduction temperature, indicating that Pt atoms in the Rh–Pt–P catalyst were more positively charged. In Rh2P, electron transfer occurs from Rh to P [22,35,36]. Therefore, the formation of Pt phosphide species or P-coordinated Pt could be expected with increase in reduction temperature. Furthermore, the E0 of the Rh K-edge spectra slightly decreased with increase in the reduction temperature at > 550 °C, as shown in Table 6. Furthermore, this E0 for the Rh K-edge was lower than that of Rh2P. These results indicate that Pt interacts with Rh to cause an electron transfer from Pt to Rh, which suggests the presence of Pt on the surface or the vicinity of Rh2P particles. Fig. 10 shows the Fourier-transformed Pt L3-edge EXAFS of the Rh–Pt–P catalyst reduced at different temperatures. In the Rh–Pt–P catalyst reduced at any temperature, there is no indication for the presence of Pt metal. The peak at distance around 0.20 nm increased with increasing reduction temperature, this peak correspond to Pt−P distance. In the PtP2, two peaks for Pt−P bond were observed at distance of 0.225 and 0.285 nm [37]. These results imply that Pt would presence as other phosphide phase and/or exist on the surface of Rh2P. Moreover, the peak at distance of 0.255 nm were observed in the Rh–Pt–P catalyst reduced above 600 °C. This distance is longer than that of 0.249 nm for Rh−Rh bonding in Rh2P ( Fig. S6 ). On the basis of these results, this peak can be attributed to Pt−Rh distance. Thus, Pt would exist on the surface of Rh2P particle. 3.4 Active sites of the Rh–Pt–P catalyst The addition of Pt to the Rh–P catalyst enhanced the C−S bond cleavage activity of C4H4S and 4,6-DMDBT. Moreover, the in situ XRD patterns revealed the formation of Rh2P after reduction at > 550 °C. Thus, Rh2P acts as an active site for HDS reactions. Moreover, the mixed Rh–P and Pt–P catalyst showed the same C−S bond cleavage activity as the Rh–P catalyst, indicating that Pt interacts with Rh2P to create highly active sites for C−S bond cleavage. In the Rh–Pt–P catalyst, Pt acts as the active site for the cleavage of C−S bonds in organic sulfur compounds, which are known to adsorb on Lewis acid sites [38,39]. Furthermore, the XANES analysis revealed the occurrence of an electron transfer from Pt to Rh. As per these results, the following active site model can be proposed. In the Rh–Pt–P catalyst, the organic sulfur compound would adsorb on the slightly positively charged Pt atoms, which act as Lewis acid sites. Moreover, as shown in Table 6, the Rh atoms in Rh2P are slightly positively charged (XANES for Rh K-edge). Considering our previous report describing the high hydrogenation activity for biphenyl of Rh2P [21], activated hydrogen species would be supplied from the Rh sites on Rh2P to the positively charged Pt sites, where the C−S bond cleavage of hydrogenated organic sulfur compounds would occur. Moreover, we have reported that Rh2P possesses a high sulfur tolerance analyzed by a temperature-programmed sulfidation technique [40]. Thus, high sulfur tolerant Rh2P would maintain high hydrogenation activity in the HDS reaction. This mechanism would explain the enhanced C–S bond cleavage activity of the Rh2P upon Pt addition. 4 Conclusions The C−S bond cleavage activity of an Rh–P catalyst was enhanced by adding Ru or Pt, which form stronger M−S bonds than Rh. In particular, the Rh–Pt–P catalyst showed higher activity for the HDS of C4H4S and 4,6-DMDBT than the Rh–P catalyst. Furthermore, the THT selectivity of the Pt–P and mixed Rh–P + Pt–P catalysts revealed that Pt and Rh cooperatively act as the active sites in the Rh–Pt–P catalyst. The characterization results revealed that the Pt present on the surface or the vicinity of Rh2P particles reacted with P to form phosphide or P-coordinated Pt species. In this catalyst, the Rh sites on Rh2P activate hydrogen and the positively charged Pt atoms serve as the active sites to cleave the C−S bonds of hydrogenated organic sulfur compounds. Overall, the high C−S bond cleavage activity of the Rh–Pt–P catalyst can be explained by this new bifunctional reaction route. coredata.dc:description: To enhance the hydrodesulfurization (HDS) activity of SiO2-supported Rh phosphide catalysts, various second metal-added Rh–P catalysts were developed; furthermore, the effect of the addition of the second metal on the HDS performance was examined. The second metals (M: Ru, Pt, and Ir) were selected as per the Sabatier principle. In situ X-ray diffraction revealed the formation of an Rh2P phase in the Rh–M–P catalyst after reduction. The addition of Ru and Pt to the Rh–P catalyst enhanced the C−S bond cleavage activity, whereas the addition of Ir had virtually no effect. The Rh–Pt–P catalyst demonstrated the highest HDS activity among Rh–M–P catalysts. The characterization results revealed the presence of positively charged Pt on the Rh–Pt–P catalyst surface, in which Pt and Rh cooperatively act as active sites to enhance the C−S bond cleavage activity.
coredata.dc:title: Enhancement of the hydrodesulfurization and C−S bond cleavage activities of rhodium phosphide catalysts by platinum addition
